title: 143 is special ...
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For how many positive integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k<10000"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" does the following statement hold ?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"67\\times k \\equiv 1 \\pmod{143}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By using Bezout's theorem we can say that there exists exactly 1 positive integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k<143"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which has the stated property . It's possible to find the number by using Bezout's theorem , as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"gcd(67,143)=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus 1 can be expressed as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"143x +67y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"143 = 2\times 67 + 9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"67 = 7 \times 9 +4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9 = 2\times 4 +1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 = 9 - 4\times 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\therefore 1 = (143 - 2\times 67) - (67- 7\times 9) 2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\therefore 1 = (143 - 2\times 67) - [2\times 67- 14(143 - 2\times 67) ] "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\therefore 1 = 143 - 2\times 67  +14\times 143 -30 \times 67"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\therefore 1 = 143 \times 15 - 67\times 30"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\therefore 1 = 143 \times 15 + 67\times (-30)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This tells us that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"67\times (-30) \equiv 1 \pmod{143}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"67\times (143-30) \equiv 1 \pmod{143}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the smallest positive integer for which given statement hold is 143-30 i.e. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"111"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The other numbers will be of the form "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"111 +143k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" as they also will be congruent to 1 mod 143 ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The multiple of 143 next to 10000 is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"143 \times 70 = 10010"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"so the biggest of our required numbers is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10010-111= 111 + 69 \times 143"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence all the numbers we require are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"111,111+143 , 111+2\times 143 ,\dots, 111+ 69\times 143"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{70}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such numbers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ............."},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(k<10000)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I have another approach..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since k is the inverse of 67, it is unique in the interval [1, 143]. Since 143 = 11 x 13, 67k is congruent to 1 modulo11 and modulo 13. By property of LCD congruence, this holds true. Using Chinese Remainder Theorem, we found out that k = 111 + 143n so k is congruent to 111 modulo 143. From this, we solve the inequality 111 + 143(n-1) < 10000. And n <= 70 < 70 + (22/143). Hence, the answer is 70."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Solution 1:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(\dfrac{1}{2})^x=4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(\dfrac{1}{2})^x=(\dfrac{1}{2})^{-2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#D61F06}\boxed{x=-2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{\text{answer}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Solution 2.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(\dfrac{1}{2})^x=4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"taking the natural logarithm of both sides, we have"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\ln~(\dfrac{1}{2})^x=\ln~4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x\ln\dfrac{1}{2}=\ln~4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=\dfrac{\ln~4}{\ln~0.5}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#D61F06}\boxed{x=-2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{\text{answer}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Marvin, please use \ln for natural log operator. Operators must not be in italics.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Every number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1 \underbrace{44 \ldots 44}_{\text{n digits}} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can be written as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 10^n + \underbrace{44 \ldots 44}_{\text{n digits}} = 10^n + 4 \cdot ( \underbrace{11 \ldots 11}_{\text{n digits}} ) = 10^n + 4 \cdot \frac {\left( 10^n-1 \right)} 9 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n \geq 2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we can factor out "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2^2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", since we only want to prove that the expression is not a perfect square."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 10^n + 4 \cdot \frac {\left( 10^n-1 \right)} 9 = 4 \cdot \left( 25 \cdot 10^{n-2} + \frac {\left( 10^n-1 \right)} 9 \right) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let's look at the remainder when dividing by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The remainder of a square number divided by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is always "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The remainder of a sum is the sum of the remainders, so the remainder of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 25 \cdot 10^{n-2} + \frac {\left( 10^n-1 \right)} 9 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the remainder of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 25 \cdot 10^{n-2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n \geq 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", plus the remainder of  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac {\left( 10^n-1 \right)} 9 = \underbrace{11 \ldots 11}_{\text{n digits}} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"To test for divisibility by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we look at the two last digits, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 11 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". They give a remainder of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" when divided by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". But since the remainder of a perfect square is either "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", this number with remainder "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" cannot be a perfect square, so there are "},{"type":"text","text":"No","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" other such numbers."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            the answer 'no' is clearly wrong. the mistake in this problem is not in the question, but in the answer. the meaning of the question is unmistakable - starts w 144, ends in 44. says nothing about the middle, which means 'whatever'. any number that starts with 12 pr 38 has enough zeroes in between and ends with 12 or 38 will fit the bill. so, the only correct answer is yes

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            The remainder of the number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1\underbrace{444\ldots444}_{n \text{ } 4\text{'s}} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is indeed "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" because it ends in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 44 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which is divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". At the end, where I mentioned the remainder "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \pmod 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", I was referring to the number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1 \underbrace {444\ldots444}_{n \text{ } 4\text{'s}} \div 4 = 36\underbrace{111\ldots111}_{(n-2) \text{ } 1\text{'s}} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". which leaves a remainder "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3 \pmod 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Every integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can be written as either "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n = 2k, k \in \mathbb{Z} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n = 2k+1, k \in \mathbb{Z} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (even and odd numbers)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If we square both forms, we get"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"blockquote","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" ( 2k )^2 = 4k^2 = 4a+0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a = k^2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"
  
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" ( 2k+1 )^2 = 4k^2+4k+1 = 4 \left( k^2+k \right) +1 = 4b+1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" b = k^2+k "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the square of an even number is always divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and the square of an odd number is always one more than a multiple of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            A square number can be written as, if even, (2c)^2 and odd as (2c+1)^2.
Divinding by 4 we get:
(2c)^2/4 = c^2    => zero remainder
(2c+1)^2/4 = (4c^2+4c+1)/4  => we can see that in this case we obtain 1 as remainder.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Sorry, if this is obvious, but why did you divide by four? If every square number mod 4 is either 0 or 1, evenly dividing by 4 means that the number has a chance to be true square number. But you factored out a 4 and then divided by 4 again? I'm a little confused as to why you needed to do this...

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            That's a nice near-miss you've found there. According to "},{"type":"text","text":"Wolphram Alpha","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":", it's only 0.00177 away from the next square number. But it's not a perfect square.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                            But what about sqrt(1444...44)? [Ps. It's 1 following by 77 digits of 4]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"** If my calc working properly, It's 2^(380058475033045993045349675188918159692)

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider the remainders of such numbers after dividing by 16.  A quick check tells us that perfect squares are always congruent to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \color{#20A900} 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \color{#20A900} 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \color{#20A900} 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \color{#20A900} 9 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo 16."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned} 14 &\equiv \color{#D61F06}14 \ \ \color{#333333} \text{mod} \ 16  \\ 144 &\equiv \ \ \color{#20A900}0 \\ 1,444 &\equiv \ \ \color{#20A900}4 \\ 14,444 &\equiv \color{#D61F06}12 \\ 144,444 &\equiv \color{#D61F06}12 \\ 1,444,444 &\equiv \color{#D61F06}12 \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 10,000 = 16 \times 625 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so every number from "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 14,444 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" on is congruent to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 4,444 \equiv \color{#D61F06}12 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" mod 16, and thus not a perfect square."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[This train of thought was inspired by Henry U factoring out "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2^2 = 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and then considering divisibility by 4.]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Oh interesting, I had the same question! But how does one think of “Hmm.. lemme check the residue mod 16? lol just asking

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Look up "},{"type":"text","text":"modular arithmetic","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":".  There are only 16 possible remainders when you divide by 16: 0, 1, 2, ..., 14, 15.  Just look at the squares of those numbers (so the perfect squares from 0 to 225) and see what the remainders are when dividing by 16.  It doesn't take too long, and you see a lot of repeated values."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0^2 = \ \ 0 = 16 \times 0 + \color{#20A900} 0 \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \color{#333333} \ \ 8^2 = \ \ 64 = 16 \times \ 4 + \color{#20A900} 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1^2 = \ \ 1 = 16 \times 0 + \color{#20A900} 1 \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \color{#333333} \ \ 9^2 = \ \ 81 = 16 \times \ 5 + \color{#20A900} 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2^2 = \ \ 4 = 16 \times 0 + \color{#20A900} 4 \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \color{#333333} 10^2 = 100 = 16 \times \ 6 + \color{#20A900} 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3^2 = \ \ 9 = 16 \times 0 + \color{#20A900} 9 \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \color{#333333} 11^2 = 121 = 16 \times \ 7 + \color{#20A900} 9 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 4^2 = 16 = 16 \times 1 + \color{#20A900} 0 \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \color{#333333} 12^2 = 144 = 16 \times \ 9 + \color{#20A900} 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 5^2 = 25 = 16 \times 1 + \color{#20A900} 9 \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \color{#333333} 13^2 = 169 = 16 \times 10 + \color{#20A900} 9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 6^2 = 36 = 16 \times 2 + \color{#20A900} 4 \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \color{#333333} 14^2 = 196 = 16 \times 12 + \color{#20A900} 4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 7^2 = 49 = 16 \times 3 + \color{#20A900} 1 \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \color{#333333} 15^2 = 225 = 16 \times 14 + \color{#20A900} 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            How does one check what perfect squares are congruent to modulo 16? Or any number, for that matter?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since any number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1444\ldots 444"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is even, it must be the square of an even number, i.e. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1444\ldots 444 = (2k)^2 = 4k^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus any "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1444\ldots 444"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a multiple of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In our case "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"144 = 12^2 = (2\cdot 6)^2 = 4\cdot 36"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1444 = 38^2 = (2\cdot 19)^2 = 4\cdot 361"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now let's take a look at "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1444\ldots 444"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" numbers "},{"type":"text","text":"with more than two","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" digits: by dividing any such number by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"361\ldots 111"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", in fact "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{{\color{#0000ff}{144}}4\ldots 444}{4} = \frac{{\color{#0000ff}{1440\ldots 000}}}{4} + \frac{4\ldots 444}{4} = {\color{#0000ff}{360\ldots 000}} + 1\ldots 111 =  {\color{#0000ff}{36}} 1\ldots 111 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Any "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"361\ldots 111"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is an odd number, thus it must be the square of an odd number, i.e. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"361\ldots 111 = (2l+1)^2 = 4l^2 + 4l +1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By rearranging we see that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"361\ldots 110 = 4l^2 + 4l = 4(l^2 + l)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i.e. any number on the left must be a multiple of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"; but any such number must be divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", thus it must have the last two digits divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which in our case is never true for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is not divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Summing up: we have just proven that any "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"361\ldots 111"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (with "},{"type":"text","text":"two or more","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" digits) can't be the square of an integer number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (see first line), so the answer is that there are "},{"type":"text","text":"no other","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1444\ldots 444"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that are perfect squares."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2=14...4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2-4=(x+2)(x-2)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a multiple of 10, so x is even and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=+/-2(mod 5)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":": combined the last digit of x must be 2 or 8.
Below, a, b and c are nonnegative integers."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1) Suppose "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=10a+2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2 = 100a^2+40a+4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"a must end on 1 or 6 "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"x must end on 12 or 62"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1.1) Suppose "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x =100b+12"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2 = 10000b^2+2400b+144 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", implying that the 3rd digit from the right in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is odd. The only possibility satisfying the pattern is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2 = 144"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1.2) Suppose "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x =100b+62"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2 =10000b^2+12400b+3844"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Now 4b+8 must end on 4, so b must end on a 4 or a 9, so x must end on 462 or 962."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1.2.1) Suppose "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=1000c+462"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2=1000000c^2+2×1000×462×c+213444"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1.2.2) Suppose "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=1000c+962"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2=1000000c^2+2×1000×962×c+925444"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For both these cases there is no solution because the digit at position 4 from the right is odd (and it cannot be the leading 1 since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2 > 1444"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":")."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Summarizing: The only solution for possibility 1) is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x=12"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2) Suppose x ends on an 8, so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=10a+8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2 = 100a^2+160a+64"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 6a+6 must end on a 4 "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 6a ends on an 8 "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" a ends on a 3 or 8. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" x ends on 38 or 88"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2.1) suppose that x ends on 38. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2=(100b+38)^2=10000b^2+7600b+1444"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Possibilities are: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=5 (mod 10)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" x ends on 038 or 538"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2.1.1) if x ends on 038, the 4th position from the right is odd so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=38"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the only solution."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2.1.2) if x ends on 538, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2=(1000c+538)^2=1000000c^2+1076c+289444"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Here too, position 4 from the right is odd and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x^2 >1444"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2.2) suppose that x ends on 88. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2=(100b+88)^2=10000b^2+17600b+7744"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Position 3 from the right is odd and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2 > 144"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Summarizing: The only solution for possibility 2) is x=38, and 12 and 38 are the only solutions for x."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I don't know much about python and runtime, but I think you could also have used"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"codeBlock","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1floor(sqrt(int('1'+'4'*j)))=sqrt(int('1'+'4'*j))


"}],"attrs":[{"text":"floor(sqrt(int('1'+'4'*j)))=sqrt(int('1'+'4'*j))
","language":null}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"That way, you generate the number, take its square root and check if it is an integer.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}
